qas.question: How long are CDs expected to last?
What can cause sudden disc degradation?
Are CDs meant for permanent or temporary use?
What can the aluminium on a disc cause reading errors?

plausible_answers.text: The design life is from 20 to 100 years

qas.question: Why does disc rot allow CD-Rs to last for years?

plausible_answers.text: degradation of some discs in as little as 18 months

qas.question: What type of environment is best for a CD-R?

context: CD-R recordings are designed to be <a2_0>permanent<a2_0/>. Over time, the dye's <b3_0>physical characteristics may change<b3_0/> causing read errors and data loss until the reading device cannot recover with error correction methods. <b4_0>The design life is from <a0_0>20 to 100 years<b4_0/><a0_0/>, depending on the quality of the discs, the quality of the writing drive, and storage conditions. However, <b6_0>testing<b6_0/> has demonstrated such <b5_0>degradation of some discs in as little as 18 months<b5_0/> under <b7_0>normal storage conditions<b7_0/>. This failure is known as <a1_0>disc rot<a1_0/>, for which there are several, mostly environmental, reasons.
